column1: Link	Title	Text
0	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-idUSKCN0Z61BS	Senate rejects gun-control measures after Orlando shooting	"
By Richard Cowan and John Whitesides
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate on Monday rejected four measures restricting gun sales after last week's massacre in an Orlando nightclub
column2: dealing a bitter setback to advocates who have failed to get even modest gun curbs through Congress despite repeated mass shootings.A group of senators was still hoping to forge a compromise for later in the week aimed at keeping firearms away from people on terrorism watch lists
column3: although that effort faced an uphill battle with critics in both parties skeptical about its chances.Last week's massacre
column4: the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history
column5: had intensified pressure on lawmakers
column6: who moved swiftly to take the issue to the Senate floor. But the gun-control measures lost in largely party-line votes that showed the lingering political power in Congress of gun rights defenders and the National Rifle Association.Republicans and their allies in the NRA gun lobby said the Democratic bills were too restrictive and trampled on the constitutional right to bear arms. Democrats attacked the Republicans' two proposals as too weak and accused them of being in the thrall of the NRA.""What am I going to tell the community of Orlando?"" asked Democratic Senator Bill Nelson of Florida after the votes. ""Sadly
column7: what I'm going to tell them is the NRA won again.""Chris Cox
column8: executive director of the National Rifle Association Institute for Legislative Action
column9: attacked the Democrats' amendments and thanked Republicans for rejecting them. ""Today
column10: the American people witnessed an embarrassing display in the United States
column11: he said.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column13: said the Democratic measures were ineffective and Republican senators ""are pursuing real solutions that can help keep Americans safer from the threat of terrorism.""As the parties remain largely locked in their positions
column14: polls show Americans are increasingly in favor of more restrictions on guns in a country with more than 310 million weapons
column15: about one for every citizen. The issue is already a prominent one for voters in November elections. Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton supports new gun restrictions
column16: while Republican Donald Trump expressed a willingness to talk to the NRA about the issue.

column1: After the votes
column2: Clinton issued a one-word statement: ""Enough."" It was followed by the names and ages of the dead in Orlando.Gun control efforts failed after mass shootings at an elementary school in Newtown
column3: Connecticut
column4: in 2012 and a conference center in San Bernardino
column5: California
column6: in 2015. But some senators see resistance to gun restrictions softening as national security looms larger in the debate.The Orlando gunman
column8: pledged allegiance to the militant group Islamic State as he killed 49 people in a gay nightclub. ""This country is under attack ... it's not a plane or an explosive device
column11: a Democrat who led a 15-hour filibuster last week to draw attention to the effort to restrict guns.

column1: 'SHAME ON EVERY SINGLE SENATOR'
Murphy walked off the floor after the Senate votes and embraced Erica Smegielski
column2: the daughter of Dawn Hochsprung
column3: a Sandy Hook principal killed during the Newtown shooting.""He said
column4: the good thing about me and you is we're young
column5: we'll be at this a long time
column6: said Smegielski
column7: 30.A Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted last week found that 71 percent of Americans favor at least moderate regulations and restrictions on gun sales. That compared with 60 percent in late 2013 and late 2014.

column1: Senior Senate aides left open the possibility of other votes later in the week on unspecified gun control proposals. Some Republicans pinned hopes on a proposal by Senator Susan Collins
column2: a Maine Republican
column3: which was not one of the four bills being considered on Monday.Collins' plan would restrict gun purchases to a narrow group of suspects
column4: including those on a ""no-fly"" list or a ""selectee"" list of people who require additional screening at airports..But Democratic aides said people credibly suspected of involvement in terrorism would not be covered by the weapons ban under Collins' bill
column5: and a Republican aide indicated it would not do enough to protect the constitutional rights of gun buyers.Even if the Senate approved a gun compromise
column6: it would also have to be passed by the more conservative
column7: Republican-majority House of Representatives. House Republican leadership aides did not comment on the possibility that any bills proposing gun restrictions would be considered on the House floor this week.On Monday
column8: all four of the measures to expand background checks on gun buyers and curb gun sales to those on terrorism watch lists - two put forth by Democrats and two by Republicans - fell short of the 60 votes needed for passage in the 100-member chamber.Gun-control advocates expressed disappointment after the vote and vowed to take revenge on lawmakers at the ballot box in November.""Shame on every single senator who voted against these life-saving amendments and protected the rights of terrorists and other dangerous people to buy guns
column10: president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence. ""The Brady Campaign will expose these politicians for who they really are and call out their failure to disarm hate in America."" (Additional reporting by Amanda Becker and Emily Stephenson; Writing by John Whitesides; Editing by Alistair Bell and Mary Milliken)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0Z61L5	Trump fires campaign manager in shakeup for election push	"
By Emily Flitter and Emily Stephenson
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON
NEW YORK/WASHINGTON Donald Trump fired Corey Lewandowski
column2: the campaign manager who helped him win Republican presidential nominating contests but clashed with other advisers on how to appeal to the broader general electorate
column3: several people with knowledge of the decision said on Monday.The firing on Monday morning was another shakeup for a campaign already at odds with many senior Republican figures over the presumptive nominee's policies
column4: with the party's nominating convention in Cleveland less than a month away. But it may also prove a step toward calming concerns among party leaders about Trump
column5: a wealthy businessman and political outsider
column6: and the conflicting advice he was getting from senior aides
column7: as he battles presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton ahead of the Nov. 8 election.Trump said Lewandowski did ""a great job"" but ""it's time now for a different kind of a campaign.""""We ran a small
column9: well-unified campaign. It worked very well in the primaries. I think I'm probably going to do some of that
column10: Trump said in an interview with Fox News
column11: in which he did not say if Lewandowski had been fired.Three people close to the campaign said some of Trump's staff viewed Lewandowski as opposing strategic changes and staff hires urged for the general election campaign by Paul Manafort
column12: a strategist hired in April partly for his experience on presidential campaigns that Lewandowski lacked.The three
column13: a campaign staffer and two people in regular contact with Trump advisers
column14: spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized by Trump to discuss the firing.Manafort will take over as campaign manager
column16: co-chairman of the campaign's operations in New York state.""Paul's in charge
column18: the Republican National Committee's communications director
column19: said in an interview.Trump's decision to fire his manager came in part at the urging of his daughter Ivanka Trump and her husband
column21: who have powerful advisory roles in the campaign
column22: the two people in contact with Trump aides said.

column1: Hope Hicks
column2: who single-handedly fields Trump's media inquiries
column3: disputed reports she had complained about Lewandowski to Ivanka Trump. ""That is entirely untrue
column4: she said.Lewandowski
column6: had been a near-constant presence at Trump's side since the New York developer launched his campaign on June 2015. In a brief statement read on CNN
column7: Lewandowski said: ""I stand by the fact that Mr. Trump is a great candidate and is better than Hillary Clinton ever will be."" Lewandowski denied there were any tensions between him and Trump's family in an interview with CNN.Later on Monday
column8: a campaign adviser resigned after reveling in Lewandowski's exit on his Twitter account

column1: Ding dong the witch is dead!"" Michael Caputo
column2: the adviser
column3: wrote shortly after reports of the firing emerged. He later released a statement to CNN saying he had resigned. ""In hindsight
column4: that was too exuberant a reaction to this personnel move
column5: his statement said.CAMPAIGN TENSIONS

column1: The RNC spokesman did not think there would be a change in Trump's tone. ""It's going to be more of a streamlined effort and more of an understanding of the difference that a general election has
column2: Spicer said.Clinton's campaign has hundreds more staff than that of Trump. In contrast to her unsuccessful 2008 presidential bid
column3: there has been no public sign this time of any significant infighting among her advisers.

column1: The former U.S. secretary of state has also spent millions of dollars on television commercials in recent weeks. Trump has not aired any paid advertisements since becoming the presumptive nominee
column2: preferring to spread his message through his Twitter account and in media interviews.Trump has faced setbacks in the past two weeks. His renewed calls to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the United States have drawn heavy criticism from Republican politicians in Washington and prompted corporate sponsors like Apple and JPMorgan Chase to withhold funding from the party's July 18-21 convention. Recent opinion polls show at least half of all voters approve of the Muslim ban.Lewandowski
column3: a former New Hampshire field director for a conservative advocacy group
column4: argued that Trump's unconventional campaigning style did not need to be changed after it proved successful in the last few months of primary contests.Lewandowski repeatedly defended that strategy with a line that became his mantra: ""Let Trump be Trump."" Known for his brusque manner
column5: Lewandowski was accused of manhandling a female reporter in Florida during the primary campaign
column6: but the battery charge against him was later dropped.He is still scheduled to attend the Cleveland convention as chairman of New Hampshire's delegation.The Democratic National Committee said Lewandowski's exit was unlikely to change Trump.""It wasn't Corey Lewandowski who called for a ban on Muslims entering the United States
column10: ""it was Donald Trump."" (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu and Eric Beech in Washington; Writing by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-arrest-idUSKCN0Z62FZ	Man arrested at Trump rally said he wanted to shoot candidate: court papers	"

A man arrested over the weekend trying to wrestle a gun from a police officer at a Las Vegas rally held by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump told an investigator he wanted to kill the candidate
column2: court papers showed on Monday.Michael Steven Sandford
column3: who prosecutors described as a 19-year-old British national
column4: was arrested on Saturday at the Treasure Island hotel in Las Vegas after trying to disarm the officer
column5: according to Las Vegas police.According to court papers filed on Monday in federal court in Nevada
column6: Sandford told a Secret Service agent he had driven to Las Vegas from California with the goal of shooting Trump.""Sandford claimed he had been attempting to kill Trump for about a year but decided to act on this occasion because he finally felt confident about trying it

column1: He was charged with committing an act of violence on restricted ground
column2: Natalie Collins
column3: a spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's Office
column4: said in an email.Sandford has not entered a plea and is scheduled to be in court for a preliminary hearing on July 5
column5: Collins said. Sandford's federal public defender
column6: Heather Fraley
column7: could not be immediately reached for comment.

column1: Sandford said he had been in the United States for a year and a half
column2: the documents showed. The records said he had lived in Hoboken
column3: New Jersey
column4: after coming to the country.Court records said Sandford went to the Battlefield Vegas gun range last Friday to practice shooting
column5: adding that he had never fired a gun before. While there
column6: he fired 20 rounds from a Glock 9 mm handgun

column1: Sandford told investigators that if he were ""on the street tomorrow
column2: he would try again
column3: the documents said. (Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles and Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Toni Reinhold and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-economikes-idUSKCN0Z712S	'Economikes': the gatekeepers of Clintonâ€™s economic policy	"
By Luciana Lopez
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Hillary Clinton has no shortage of economic advisors. Scores of world-class experts pour ideas into her campaign on the policies she should champion in her bid for the White House.But before much of the input reaches the Democratic candidate
column2: it is filtered through a pair of staffers known inside the campaign as the ""Economikes.""Working out of Clinton's campaign headquarters in Brooklyn
column3: New York
column4: Michael Shapiro and Michael Schmidt are helping shape what could be a lasting economic agenda if the former secretary of state overcomes Republican rival Donald Trump in November's election.In an interview with Reuters
column5: Shapiro and Schmidt described Clinton's process for forming policy by broadly soliciting ideas and crafting them into the action points that she takes to voters. Before Clinton takes a position
column6: Shapiro said
column7: ""she wants to know we have talked to and gotten input from everyone
column8: making sure that we're consulting with labor
column9: making sure that we're consulting with experts.""Clinton's inclusive approach to developing policy positions has been faulted for being slow and unwieldy. Much of the work of sifting through the wealth of sometimes disparate ideas and data it yields falls to the Economikes.Both are recent graduates of Yale Law School. Prior to joining the campaign
column12: worked at the U.S. Treasury Department and the Yale Investments Office
column15: worked at the White House for the National Economic Council. Earlier this year
column16: he married the daughter of New York Senator Chuck Schumer.The pair helps Clinton draw upon a deep bench of advisers
column18: Duke professor Aaron Chatterji and Simon Johnson
column19: a former chief economist for the International Monetary Fund
column20: along with scores of other academics and business people.

column1: Some communicate regularly through emails
column2: conference calls
column3: meetings and memos. Others are tapped once or twice for specific expertise. Frequent contributor Alan Blinder
column4: the former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve
column5: said he will ""usually email the Mikes"" with ideas.The fruit of the process will be on display today in Ohio
column6: where Clinton is expected to give a speech contrasting her economic vision with that of Trump
column7: a businessman who often names himself as his main adviser and is known for his off-the-cuff style.Clinton has called raising middle class incomes the defining economic challenge of the time. So far
column8: she has presented a mix of goals
column9: including making child care more affordable and boosting jobs. Some business leaders have said her approach is reassuring
column10: but progressives have criticized her policies as too moderate.Trump
column12: often has taken business leaders by surprise with his policy proposals. He has promised to renegotiate international trade deals to pump up U.S. manufacturing
column13: vowed to penalize companies that move their headquarters abroad to avoid taxes
column14: and pledged to dismantle Obama's financial regulation reforms.

column1: ""ONE OF THE MIKES""
While the ""Economikes"" nickname began as a joke
column2: Shapiro said the campaign's digital team made it stick by using it in a Q&A posted on Clinton's web site.Their bosses
column3: senior policy advisers Jake Sullivan and Maya Harris
column4: have been known to stick their heads out of their offices and ask for ""one of the Mikes.""On email chains
column5: CC: notes will sometimes include ""plus the Economikes.""

column1: Humor aside
column2: their work often is serious business.After the tainted water crisis hit national headlines in January
column3: Clinton dispatched Schmidt and her political director
column4: Amanda Renteria
column5: to Flint
column6: Michigan to investigate. Schmidt said the effort informed Clinton's approach to the water crisis during the Democratic debate in Flint
column7: including her call for the governor to resign.    In other cases
column9: Clinton will ask the pair to research issues she's heard on the campaign trail
column10: such as the case of an Iowa bowling alley owner who told the candidate student debt made it hard for him to get business loans.The campaign since has rolled out proposals to allow for refinancing of student debt and the use of income-based repayment programs to cut monthly payments.Shapiro and Schmidt said the policy points they bring back to Clinton typically lead her to ask more questions
column11: a process that can go on for several rounds before the candidate finally settles on a policy proposal. (Additional reporting by Amanda Becker
column13: and Adam DeRose in Washington; editing by Richard Valdmanis and Lisa Girion)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-cyber-fbi-emails-idUSKCN0Z7056	Invoking Orlando
column2: Senate Republicans set up vote to expand FBI spying	"

column1: By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell set up a vote late on Monday to expand the Federal Bureau of Investigation's authority to use a secretive surveillance order without a warrant to include email metadata and some browsing history information.The move
column2: made via an amendment to a criminal justice appropriations bill
column3: is an effort by Senate Republicans to respond to last week's mass shooting in an Orlando nightclub after a series of measures to restrict guns offered by both parties failed on Monday.""In the wake of the tragic massacre in Orlando
column4: it is important our law enforcement have the tools they need to conduct counterterrorism investigations
column5: Senator John McCain
column6: an Arizona Republican and sponsor of the amendment
column7: said in a statement. The bill is also supported by Republican Senators John Cornyn
column9: who chairs the Senate Intelligence Committee.Privacy advocates denounced the effort
column10: saying it seeks to exploit a mass shooting in order to expand the government's digital spying powers.

column1: Senator Ron Wyden
column2: an Oregon Democrat
column3: criticized a similar effort last month as one that ""takes a hatchet to important protections for Americans' liberty.""The amendment would broaden the FBI's authority to use so-called National Security Letters to include electronic communications transaction records such as time stamps of emails and the emails' senders and recipients.

column1: The Obama administration for years has lobbied for a change to how NSLs can be used
column2: after a 2008 legal memo from the Justice Department said the law limits them largely to phone billing records. FBI Director James Comey has said the change essentially corrects a typo and is a top legislative priority for his agency.NSLs do not require a warrant and are almost always accompanied by a gag order preventing the service provider from sharing the request with a targeted user.The letters have existed since the 1970s
column3: though the scope and frequency of their use expanded greatly after the Sept. 11
column5: attacks on the United States.

column1: The amendment filed Monday would also make permanent a provision of the USA Patriot Act that allows the intelligence community to conduct surveillance on ""lone wolf"" suspects who do not have confirmed ties to a foreign terrorist group. That provision
column2: which the Justice Department said last year had never been used
column3: is currently set to expire in December 2019.A vote is expected no later than Wednesday
column4: McConnell's office said. (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-muslims-idUSKCN0Z62LK	American Muslims see Trump rhetoric fueling prejudice
column2: hate incidents	"

column1: By Yara Bayoumy
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON About three months ago
column2: Sarah Ibrahim's son came home from his fourth-grade class at a Maryland school with a disturbing question.""Will I have time to say goodbye to you before you're deported?"" he said
column3: according to Ibrahim
column4: a Muslim Arab American who works at a federal government agency in Maryland.""The kids in his classroom were saying: 'Who's going to leave when Trump becomes president?'"" said the 35-year-old mother.The incident happened a few months after Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump -- now the presumptive nominee -- first called for a ban on Muslim immigrants and for more scrutiny at mosques after 14 people were killed in San Bernardino by a Muslim couple whom the FBI said had been radicalized.Trump intensified his anti-Muslim rhetoric after last week's mass shooting in Orlando
column5: in which a U.S.-born Muslim man killed 49 people at a gay nightclub
column6: calling for a suspension of immigration from countries with ""a proven history of terrorism"".He reiterated his call for more surveillance of mosques and warned that radical Muslims were ""trying to take over our children."" While Democratic and several Republican leaders have distanced themselves from Trump's comments
column7: many American Muslims say his stance has fueled an atmosphere in which some may feel they can voice prejudices or attack Muslims without fear of retribution.""What Trump did was make these hidden thoughts public. He gave people permission to speak out loud
column8: he removed the shame associated with being prejudiced. People know that they won't be punished
column9: Ibrahim told Reuters at a community iftar
column10: the sundown meal during the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.Trump's campaign did not respond to Reuters' request for comment. Trump has rejected the criticism that his rhetoric is racist
column11: and has said he is often misunderstood by the media and his opponents.

column1: A report by the Council on American-Islamic Relations and University of California
column2: Berkeley released on Monday said the number of recorded incidents in which mosques were targeted jumped to 78 in 2015
column3: the most since the body began tracking them in 2009. There were 20 and 22 such incidents in the previous two years
column4: respectively. The incidents include verbal threats and physical attacks.Corey Saylor
column5: CAIR's director of the department to monitor and combat Islamophobia
column6: said there had been a spike in Islamophobic incidents in the wake of Orlando
column7: including those  targeting mosques.""Trump's rhetoric is a direct threat to American principles. He has mainstreamed anti-Constitutional ideas like banning or surveilling people based on faith
column8: Saylor told Reuters.""Such divisive rhetoric contributes to a toxic environment in which some people take the law into their own hands and attack people of institutions they perceive as Muslim.""

column1: DIVIDING THE COUNTRY""

CAIR says the last big spike in incidents targeting mosques was seen in 2010 following the controversy over locating an Islamic center near the site of the Sept. 11 attacks in New York.It said that lent ""additional weight to the argument that levels of anti-Muslim sentiment follow trends in domestic U.S. politics
column2: not international terrorism"".American rabbis and preachers have also denounced Trump's rhetoric. Anti-Semitic incidents in the United States still outstrip those against Muslims. The Anti-Defamation League said last year there were 912 anti-Semitic incidents across the United States during the 2014 calendar year
column3: up 21 percent from 2013.

column1: If Muslims are not free and safe in America
column2: then Christians and Jews are not free and safe in America
column3: said Rabbi Eric Yoffie
column4: president emeritus of the Union for Reform Judaism.Trump has also drawn criticism for his rhetoric against Latino immigrants
column5: saying early in his campaign that Mexican ""rapists"" and other criminals were coming across the border and calling for all undocumented immigrants to be deported.Manal Omar
column6: a Muslim-American author based in Washington
column7: said she has stopped taking the metro and walking alone late at night.""I can't dismiss the tweets and angry messages I've received from right wing militants
column9: who says she has grown especially vigilant after last week's murder of British lawmaker Jo Cox
column10: whom she knew.A few days after the San Bernardino attack
column11: Ilhaam Hassan's family restaurant was burned down in an arson attack in Grand Forks
column12: North Dakota. Matthew Gust pleaded guilty in May to federal hate-crime and arson charges. He admitted to setting the fire because of the national origin of the employees and customers at the restaurant -- a focal point of the local Somali-American community.""I don't know what to expect if he (Trump) becomes the president
column13: Hassan said. ""He is against minorities. He is against Islam. It's not a message of unity
column14: it's a message of dividing the country and that is not what America is based on."" (Additional reporting by David Bailey in Minnesota and Isma'il Kushkush in Washington; Editing by Stuart Grudgings)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-biden-idUSKCN0Z62LO	In separate speeches Obama
column2: Biden
column3: Carter target Trump policies	"

column1: By Yeganeh Torbati
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama
column2: his vice president and defense secretary took aim on Monday at policies of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump they said would alienate Muslims globally along with U.S. allies and neighbors.In a speech focusing on national security at a think tank in Washington
column3: Vice President Joe Biden said Trump's calls to bar the entry of Muslims and to profile Muslim Americans reflected the politics of fear and intolerance.""There are 1.4 billion Muslims in the world"" Biden said. ""Some of the rhetoric I'm hearing sounds designed to radicalize all 1.4 billion.""   Biden's attacks on Trump as an isolationist
column4: and others by Obama and Defense Secretary Ash Carter represent an unusually early and vigorous assault on an opposing party's presidential nominee. The election is on Nov. 8.Referring to Trump's vow to erect a wall on the U.S. border with Mexico if elected
column5: Biden said that the most complex threats do not respect borders and a wall would destroy much of the progress the Obama administration had made with U.S. neighbors.

column1: If we build walls and disrespect our neighbors
column2: we will quickly see all this progress evaporating
column3: replaced by a return of anti-Americanism
column4: a corrosive rift throughout our hemisphere
column5: Biden said.OBAMA
column6: CARTER JOIN FRAY

column1: Obama
column2: who last week assailed Trump for what he called a ""dangerous"" mindset and ""loose talk and sloppiness"" in defining the country's enemies
column3: on Monday criticized  Trump's anti-trade policies in a speech at a U.S. Commerce Department conference.""This is not just about jobs and trade
column4: it's not just about hard
column5: cold cash. It's also about building relationships across borders
column6: Obama told the 2
column7: 400 people from 70 countries at the conference to attract foreign investment.Trump has threatened to impose steep tariffs on Chinese and Mexican imports and demanded a change in a U.S. trade policy he says allows other countries to shut out U.S imports
column8: devalue their currencies and unfairly target U.S. industries.

column1: Speaking at the same event as Biden
column2: Carter said a critical part of U.S. leadership is its ""longtime network of allies and partners in every corner of the world.""""Our allies around the world have stood with us - and fought with us - time and again
column3: most recently in Iraq
column4: Afghanistan
column5: and against ISIL
column6: he said
column7: using an acronym for Islamic State.Carter did not mention Trump
column8: who has called NATO ""obsolete"" and said he would consider letting Japan and South Korea develop their own nuclear weapons rather than relying on the United States for protection against North Korea and China.While Obama
column9: Carter and other top officials generally have refrained from attacking Trump by name
column10: Obama administration spokesmen have not denied that such remarks are directed at the presumptive Republican candidate. (Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton and John Walcott in Washington; Editing by John Walcott and Howard Goller)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-democrats-idUSKCN0Z62LM	Senate blocks Democrats' plan to deny firearms to those on 'watch lists'	"

WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate on Monday blocked Democratic legislation aimed at stopping sales of firearms to people on ""terrorism watch lists.""The Senate fell 13 votes short of clearing the measure for approval
column2: as the chamber also defeated three other gun control measures stemming from the June 12 shootings in Orlando that killed 49 people and wounded 53 others.

column1: (Reporting By Richard Cowan and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Mary Milliken)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-watchlist-idUSKCN0Z62K6	Senate blocks Republican plan on 'watch list' gun sales	"

WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate on Monday blocked a Republican plan for keeping terrorism suspects from buying weapons by establishing a 72-hour review period for delaying the transactions.The Senate fell seven votes short of clearing the way for approving the measure. The Senate is now set to vote on a more sweeping Democratic proposal to keep guns out of the hands of people on terrorism watch lists.
(Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by Mary Milliken)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-loophole-idUSKCN0Z62JH	Senate blocks Democratic plan to expand gun background checks	"
WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate on Monday blocked Democratic legislation expanding federal background checks to all gun sales
column2: including those done at gun shows and on the internet.The Senate fell 16 votes short of the 60 needed for advancing the measure
column3: which would have closed a background check loophole. The Senate is now set to vote on two other gun control measures.

column1: (Reporting By Richard Cowan and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Mary Milliken)"
